Sad to see this trend üìâ"

"At one point, I was running a full Bitcoin node with Lightning, managing many inbound and outbound channels, and close to 1 BTC of liquidity. I believed deeply in helping the network grow."
""
"But here‚Äôs the reality:"
"‚ö° The technical barrier for many users is still high, making self-custody Lightning adoption difficult."
"‚ö° Third-party Lightning services could be far more user-friendly, reliable, and rewarding."
""
"For those new to it:"
""
"Lightning Network (LN) is a Layer 2 payment network built on top of Bitcoin. It allows instant, cheap transactions by creating payment channels between users ‚Äî but you need to lock up liquidity and maintain your node to keep it running."
""
"Liquid Network is another Layer 2, but it works differently. It‚Äôs a Bitcoin sidechain run by a federation of functionaries. It‚Äôs great for faster, confidential transactions and token issuance, but it‚Äôs not as decentralized as Lightning or Bitcoin‚Äôs base layer."
""
""
"Pros:"
"‚úÖ Lightning ‚Äì Instant, low-fee payments; decentralized if self-hosted."
"‚úÖ Liquid ‚Äì Privacy features, fast settlement, asset issuance."
""
"Cons:"
"‚ö† Lightning ‚Äì Complex setup for self-custody; requires active management; liquidity constraints."
"‚ö† Liquid ‚Äì Requires trust in a federation; not censorship-resistant to the same degree as Bitcoin‚Äôs main chain."
""
"Bitcoin is unstoppable. But for these Layer 2s to fulfill their promise, we must lower barriers, improve UX, and empower more people to run their own setups ‚Äî rather than relying solely on centralized services."
""
"The future is multi-layered, but only if we keep building."
""
"#Bitcoin #LightningNetwork #LiquidNetwork #BTC #Layer2 #CryptoInnovation #Decentralization"

"We're seeing more and more cases where artificial intelligence is being combined with phone spoofing to deceive people and trick them into transferring money. And here's the scary part: they no longer need hours of audio to clone your voice ‚Äî just a few minutes will do."
""
"If you‚Äôve ever uploaded a video or spoken in a podcast, interview, or livestream, congrats ‚Äî there‚Äôs already enough data out there to impersonate you."
""
"This isn‚Äôt paranoia, it‚Äôs just smart defense. Many CEOs and high-profile individuals now use pre-agreed code words or phrases with family or trusted contacts to verify authenticity during sensitive calls."
""
"Personally, I had a running joke with a friend: ‚Äî‚ÄúThey say it‚Äôs really cold today.‚Äù ‚Äî‚ÄúYeah, but people still go swimming at the beach.‚Äù"
""
"Total nonsense. But nonsense that could save you. If someone doesn‚Äôt respond with the expected phrase ‚Äî red flag."
""
"üëâ Consider setting up a verbal passphrase with your loved ones, financial advisor, lawyer, or anyone critical. It costs nothing and could save you from losing a lot ‚Äî money or worse."
""
"AI is moving fast. Let‚Äôs not make it easy for scammers to keep up."

Todo este revuelo sobre los ordenadores cu√°nticos capaces de robar claves privadas de Bitcoin suena alarmante, pero en la mayor√≠a de los casos es puro sensacionalismo."
"Pi√©nsalo as√≠: si una m√°quina cu√°ntica pudiera realmente romper las matem√°ticas que protegen Bitcoin, tambi√©n podr√≠a romper cualquier otro sistema de cifrado ‚Äîcomo el de tu banco online, tu cuenta de Netflix o incluso tu correo electr√≥nico."
"De hecho, la propia BlackRock ha advertido que un avance cu√°ntico as√≠ ‚Äúsocavar√≠a la viabilidad‚Äù de la criptograf√≠a en toda la industria tecnol√≥gica."
"As√≠ que culpar √∫nicamente a Bitcoin es como preocuparse por una sola cerradura cuando alguien ha construido una llave maestra capaz de abrirlas todas."
""
""
"---"
""
"Tranquilidad: todav√≠a queda mucho camino"
""
"Pongamos las cosas en perspectiva."
"Los ordenadores cu√°nticos actuales a√∫n est√°n en una fase muy temprana."
"Como dice Coindesk de forma bastante directa: ‚Äúno existe a√∫n ninguna m√°quina capaz de romper el cifrado de Bitcoin‚Äù."
"La m√°s potente de IBM ronda los 1.100 c√∫bits, y la de Google apenas llega a los 53."
"La mayor√≠a de expertos coinciden en que estamos, como m√≠nimo, a entre 10 y 20 a√±os de que exista una cu√°ntica lo suficientemente potente como para representar una amenaza real."
"Y en tecnolog√≠a, dos d√©cadas son una eternidad. Para entonces, ya habr√° nuevas defensas en marcha."
""
""
"---"
""
"Todos tendr√°n que actualizarse (y podr√°n hacerlo)"
""
"Mientras tanto, los desarrolladores no est√°n de brazos cruzados."
"Ya existen propuestas y avances concretos hacia criptograf√≠a ‚Äúpost-cu√°ntica‚Äù."
"Si la amenaza cu√°ntica se hace realidad, Bitcoin (igual que el resto de sistemas) podr√° actualizar su protocolo a claves resistentes."
"Es como cambiar todas las cerraduras del edificio cuando alguien inventa una herramienta capaz de abrirlas todas."
"De hecho, investigadores de IBM han calculado que incluso un ordenador cu√°ntico del futuro tardar√≠a unos 100.000 millones de a√±os en romper el cifrado AES-128 que protege hoy servicios como Netflix o la banca online."
"Bitcoin puede aguantar eso... y para entonces, todo Internet habr√° cambiado sus ‚Äúcerraduras‚Äù tambi√©n."
""
""
"---"
""
"La verdadera conclusi√≥n"
""
"La pr√≥xima vez que alguien saque el argumento de ‚Äúla cu√°ntica acabar√° con Bitcoin‚Äù, respira hondo."
"No se trata de una vulnerabilidad espec√≠fica de Bitcoin, sino de una amenaza global a los sistemas de cifrado actuales."
"Si las m√°quinas cu√°nticas llegan a ser tan potentes como se teme, afectar√°n a todo: desde las tarjetas bancarias hasta las redes sociales."
"Microsoft o Mastercard ser√°n de los primeros en actualizarse, pero Bitcoin no se quedar√° atr√°s."
""
"Por ahora, calma: la comunidad de Bitcoin est√° atenta, la criptograf√≠a resistente a cu√°ntica ya est√° en desarrollo, y el riesgo, aunque real, a√∫n queda lejos."
""
"

All this buzz about quantum computers stealing Bitcoin keys sounds scary, but it‚Äôs mostly hype. Think of it this way: if a quantum computer could really break Bitcoin‚Äôs math, it could break any encryption out there ‚Äì your online bank, Netflix account, or email password would be toast too. In fact, BlackRock warns that such a quantum breakthrough would ‚Äúundermine the viability‚Äù of cryptography across the entire tech industry, not just Bitcoin. So blaming Bitcoin alone is like worrying about one lock when someone built a skeleton key for every door ‚Äì quantum would open them all."
""
"Don‚Äôt Panic ‚Äì It‚Äôs Decades Away"
""
"Here‚Äôs some perspective: today‚Äôs quantum computers are puny. As Coindesk bluntly notes, ‚Äúno such machine exists yet‚Äù to crack Bitcoin-level encryption ‚Äì IBM‚Äôs biggest has ~1,100 qubits and Google‚Äôs only 53. Experts generally agree we‚Äôre still 10‚Äì20 years (or more) from a quantum supercomputer that could threaten Bitcoin. That‚Äôs a long time in tech years. By then, engineers will likely have rolled out the next-generation defenses."
""
"Everyone Will (Eventually) Upgrade"
""
"Meanwhile, developers aren‚Äôt ignoring this. Plans for ‚Äúpost-quantum‚Äù cryptography are already on the table. If quantum ever did materialize, we could simply hard-fork or patch Bitcoin (and everything else) to new, quantum-safe keys. Think of it like swapping to a better lock when someone invents a master key. In fact, IBM researchers point out that even a future quantum machine would need about 100 billion years to crack the AES-128 encryption that keeps Netflix and online banking safe today. Bitcoin can hold off that long ‚Äì and by then the whole internet will have updated its locks too."
""
"The Real Takeaway"
""
"So next time someone waves the ‚Äúquantum will kill Bitcoin‚Äù flag, just smile. This is a general encryption issue, not a secret Bitcoin flaw. If quantum computers ever really get that strong, everything from credit cards to social media will be in the same boat ‚Äì Microaoft or Mastercard might be the first to fix it, but Bitcoin‚Äôs not far behind. For now, keep calm: Bitcoin‚Äôs community is savvy, quantum-resistant crypto is already in development, and the threat is everywhere (it‚Äôs not a Bitcoin-only boogeyman)."
""
"Key points:"
""
"Quantum computers could eventually break all current public-key encryption ‚Äì not just Bitcoin‚Äôs."
""
"It‚Äôs not going to happen overnight. Experts say any real quantum threat is a decade or two away (IBM notes AES-128 could last on the order of 10<sup>11</sup> years under quantum)."
""
"By the time that day comes, everyone will have switched to quantum-safe cryptography."
""
"In short: Don‚Äôt sweat it. If quantum can pick one lock, it can pick them all ‚Äì and engineers are already cooking up fixes for everything."
""
"

People who "worry" about or disingenuously use the "Quantum Computing will break Bitcoin' private and public key pairs" narrative as an excuse to not own bitcoin or tell others not to. Should worry about the encryption they use to make "safe payments" online or the pin number they use for their debit card. Think about all the data stored and encrypted as social security numbers or personal details "protected" and stored by big businesses or governments. If quantum breaks encryption its not only Bitcoin that will upgrade the protocol and react to be quantum resistant. Your Netflix account will also need to react so that someone from the other side of the world can't access your movies and watch stuff for free.

""
"Imagina un escenario en el que el dinero tenga fecha de caducidad para incentivar el gasto en momentos determinados o en el que se limiten las compras de servicios esenciales‚Äîcomo billetes de tren o avi√≥n‚Äîal agotar un ‚Äúcupo de uso‚Äù basado en la huella de carbono. O peor a√∫n, considera la posibilidad de que se congelen o confisquen fondos bajo criterios arbitrarios, afectando incluso el acceso a bienes culturales o informativos, en funci√≥n de que estos se consideren contrarios a ciertos intereses gubernamentales."

"Estos posibles escenarios no solo ponen en riesgo nuestra autonom√≠a financiera, sino que tambi√©n amenazan pilares fundamentales de nuestra sociedad, como la libertad de expresi√≥n y el acceso a la informaci√≥n. En palabras de George Orwell en ‚Äú1984‚Äù: ‚ÄúSi quieres hacerte una idea de c√≥mo ser√° el futuro, imagina una bota aplastando un rostro humano incesantemente.‚Äù"
""
"Invito a todos a reflexionar sobre estos desaf√≠os √©ticos y sociales, y a participar en el debate sobre c√≥mo asegurar que la innovaci√≥n digital no comprometa nuestros derechos fundamentales.

I have completed a TryHackMe room on Cybersecurity Governance and Regulation, and it was a fantastic refresher on the critical importance of protecting sensitive information."
"The module covered key topics such as:"
"Governance, risk management, and compliance (GRC): Understanding the essential components of a GRC framework and how to develop an effective program."
"Laws and regulations: Exploring key regulations like GDPR and PCI DSS, and understanding their purpose and impact."
"Information security frameworks: Learning about ISO/IEC 27001, NIST 800-53, and other frameworks that provide guidance on implementing security controls."
"With the ever-increasing threat landscape, robust security measures are more crucial than ever. A proactive understanding of cybersecurity governance and regulation is essential for any professional in this space."
"#cybersecurity #GRC #GDPR #PCIDSS #ISO27001 #NIST #securityframeworks #dataprivacy #compliance
